question: In issue number 141 of The Fantastic Four, published in November 1973, Reed Richards has to use his anti-matter weapon on his own son, who Annihilus has turned into a human atom bomb. His son is the result of Richards' coupling with the earthling Sue Storm, and the problem is that the cosmic rays that infused Richards and the rest of the Fantastic Four on their aborted moon mission have made young Franklin a volatile mixture of matter and anti-matter. And that's what it is to come from a family, if you analyze it closely. Each of them is negative matter for the other ones. And that's what dying is -- dying is when your family, which is in fact your personal negative matter from which you emerge -- it's when the family takes you back, thus hurling you back into negative space... So it's a paradox -- the closer you're drawn back in, the further into the void you're thrown.
answer: Arise and shine, young Hood.

question: I hope you changed the water in that bong from last night.
answer: The water, as you call it, is a special mixture of amaretto and Ben&Ben blended for just the exact chemical interaction with the last of our precious Thai stick. Waste not Master Hood -- that was $20 for the bag.

question: Man, Francis, you are one drug addled elitist freak, and when the revolution comes I do not want to be lined up with you and shot, 'cause you're fucking ripe for political reeducation, you know, like in the fields.
answer: Paul, cancel your mental appointments, baby. What are you, like still stoned from last night?

question: I gotta get to English class.
answer: What Dostoyevsky is saying here is that to be a Christian is to choose, because you have to choose of your own choice, but since you can't choose to be good because that would be too rational you have to choose to be bad -- it's existential.

question: Um, Libbets. Hey, Dostoyevsky, I'm also really a fan, and what you were saying, you know, have you ever read The Idiot?
answer: The Idiot?

question: If you liked Notes from Underground, you'll love The Idiot.

question: The Idiot. I'm in love with Libbets Casey.

question: It's beyond mere physical attraction.
answer: That's good, because I don't think Libbets is capable of the sex act.

question: Truly? Do speak.
answer: My diagnosis is messed in the head. A poor little rich girl -- I mean check out the jeans and fur look. And lend your ears to this brutality. Like her mom and step dad and her step-sisters are going to Switzerland to ski over Thanksgiving break -- and like they didn't invite her!

question: How do you know this shit?
answer: They did it last year too. It's like traditional or something. They've got this humongoid Park Ave apartment and she just holes up there with a wad of cash. Aren't the hugely wealthy sad?

question: You think Francis is going to beat me to the punch here?
answer: Since he sleeps with every girl you ever show an interest in, why don't you just keep your Libbets thing a secret from him?

question: Good thinking Marge. No more man. I'm about to drop as it is.
answer: See ya.

question: Where you going?
answer: Paul, let me enlighten you about something. You and I exist on two opposite sides of a great existential divide, that being your pathetic virginity on the one hand and my astonishing number of sexual conquests on the other. I'm off to get laid. See you.

question: Flame on, asshole.
answer: And remember, with your erogenous zones lubricated as such with the mighty herb, do not attempt terrestrial contact with members of the opposite sex -- because you drone on like a motherfucker when you're stoned.

question: -- because I've been reading Kerouac and Ginsberg and those guys were creating beat culture and traveling and sleeping wherever, and, of course, with all kinds of people, but when you read carefully the various contemporary accounts of their lives, and, uh, these guys didn't bathe much, I mean they were really filthy, with like genital crabs, lice, exceptionally strong body odor... How can you do that man?

question: Sleep all day. I mean, look, it's already getting dark outside, and you're just getting up.

question: What do you mean?

question: Shit. You're not planning --

question: He's either got his head in the clouds or up his --

answer: Oh.

question: -- he knows that when the March 24th tape -- you know with Dean, where Dean tells him that there's a cancer growing on the presidency -- Who? No way. He's like a big infected whitehead wearing jeans. I wouldn't -- -- shit, it's my parents.
answer: You'd think she'd learn how to cook a chicken, eh? My drumstick was still frozen when you cut inside there. I'm probably going to get whatever that disease -- and Jim, how that guy ever became a millionaire -- Hmm. I knew she'd still be up. Watch this --

question: Elena.
answer: Sleep in the study? Please.

question: Good night.
answer: Good night.

question: But what, exactly, is stagflation, this mixture of inflation and stagnation, and how should we in the securities industry understand and accommodate it? Well -- and I hope I'm not out of bounds here - think of the money supply as a large male organ, continuously inflating, and yet, the societal vaginal cavity simply wants more. As the vicious circle of higher returns without real satisfaction continues, the money-organ may seem to be in demand, but in fact even the most inflated capital is unwanted. This is why I suggest that while we engage this mawing abyss for the highest returns, we at the same time fantasize, so to speak, of the safe harbor of capital appreciation.
answer: Hey there Benjie, you're becoming quite the in-house philosopher. When do you have time to think up all that stuff -- Shackley sure eats it up.

question: George, I'm just trying to get a global view of things -- can't just look at the small picture.
answer: And speaking of which, you have those market share charts Mr. Shackley was asking about?

question: Gotcha George, not a problem. Tomorrow. Hey, you want to start covering the old filmed entertainment sector yourself?

question: Up the organization! Bastard.
answer: I'd asked for that double martini about three hours ago! So asking me out for lunch -- what prompted this exceptional event? -- Of course I'm paying.

question: We don't have to always go to your club, dad.

question: -- Well what am I supposed to call you?
answer: That's besides the point.

question: I was actually trying to see about getting a little advice, you know --
answer: Advice? I'm supposed to be getting the stock tips from you, Ben. Unless - have you quit your job? They fired you?

question: You know, dah-- Actually it's not about work, it's advice about --
answer: Oh for crying out loud Ben, you don't mean to tell me that your marriage is going down the drain now --

question: Well, Elena and I have kind of been talking, not really talking, but --
answer: -- Your mother, God bless her, stood by me for forty-two years -- we never once contemplated divorce - I assume you're talking here about divorce? The very thought --

question: But dad, you guys truly hated each other, I mean really hated each --
answer: -- Waiter! Where's my cobb salad? You want advice Ben? If your big brother were still alive I'd have him go out into the back yard and beat some sense into your head. Look kid, you married that woman against my advice --

question: -- What advice? You never --
answer: That's besides the point. The point is if I'd had any sense in me I'd have divorced your mother 40 years ago, and that's the truth, and here it is, 1972 -- -- 73, and divorce is as easy as paying off a traffic ticket, and for crying out loud, Ben, be a man and just get it over with. I would have if I'd had the chance.

question: But...
answer: But what?

question: But I -- well maybe I love her. Elena.
answer: Christ Ben! Make up your mind and eat your lunch.

question: Elena. Elena Hood, am I right?
answer: Yes.

question: Reverend Edwards. Philip Edwards. You came by and checked out the congregation a couple of times last year.
answer: Yes, it was -- I ended up --

question: It's been a tremendously transformative year -- maybe a little controversial of course, but we're breaking down the old Unitarian barriers --
answer: I suppose my reluctance was the group aspect of it -- I've never been much of a joiner, although I still consider myself a somewhat religious person --

question: Well I of course flatter myself that our church is not exactly what most people would call organized religion -- at times it's the disorganization that's liberating -- and of course I've begun to minister much more in what one might call therapeutic environments, in small groups, and one on one, couples --
answer: My daughter. I haven't been on a bike for years. When was the last time you rode a bike?

question: They say you never forget.
answer: Forget what?

question: Forget how to ride a bike.
answer: No, of course you don't, you're right.

question: Hey Wendy.
answer: Hey Sandy.

question: Mikey was looking for you.

question: Want some gum?

question: I'm chewing.

question: We were golfing, and you know, golfing to me is something I'm supposed to enjoy, and I was on the goddam golf team in college, so it's something one would assume I do well -- I used to do well -- but basically these days golfing for me is like hoeing, or plowing. It's like farming. I am basically chewing up large tracts of expensively landscaped scenery with overpriced sticks, and George Clair has obviously, in the mere two years since he joined the firm, he has obviously been taking secret lessons with a golf pro, and I assume the entirety of his disposable income has been devoted to humiliating me on the golf course. And the guy talks - incessantly -- throughout the entirety of the miserable 18 holes - on topics that are the supposed domain of my department --
answer: Ben--

question: Yeah?
answer: You're boring me. I have a husband. I don't particularly feel the need for another.

question: You have a point there. That's a very good point. We're having an affair. Right. An explicitly sexual relationship. Your needs. My needs. You're absolutely right.
answer: You should probably get dressed. The boys will be home soon.

question: With Mikey?

question: Nobody.

question: We were just riding around.

question: Well, I saw what I saw, and if you don't want to believe me --

question: Why are you so good at math but not in English?
answer: I'm not good at math. Just geometry. It's like, you know when they say "two squared"? And you think it means 2 times 2, equals 4? But really they really mean a square. A square with a side of two. And the area of the square is four. Like every time you use the word, like squared, or cubed, it's really space, it's not numbers, it's space. And it's perfect space, but only in your head, because you can't draw a perfect square, like in the material world, but in your mind, you can have perfect space. You know?

question: Wendy!

question: When worlds collide.
answer: Huh?

question: I mean, he's not serious, he'll end up living off Janey and Jim, you watch. It's just that you develop a sense when you get older, if things are going to work out or if they won't, and sometimes it's not worth the mess... Your toes cold?
answer: Yeah.

question: I'll carry you up the drive.
answer: Dinner in ten minutes.

question: You go dry off now. Never guess where I found her. In the basement over at Janey and Jim's. With that weirdo Mikey. Not even a TV on. And they're on the floor and he's got his trousers down though thank goodness she's still dressed. Well, I really let him have it! ... and Wendy came home peacefully... Hey, should I dress for the Halford's now, or - give me your -
answer: Up to you. I'd like to go early and leave pretty soon after that.

question: I get you loud and clear... hey, you look nice.
answer: So what were you doing in the Williams' basement anyway?

question: Oh, just dropping off a coffee cup. Jim left it, last time he was over. It was on the dash of the car. You were, you know, reading, thought I'd just catch some air. Let's eat.
answer: Oh right. The mustache coffee cup. The one that was sitting on the dash.

question: Yeah, that one.
answer: That one.

question: What's for dessert?
answer: See for yourself.

question: No advice from the experts, huh?

question: You think I --
answer: I have no idea.

question: What's on your mind? Don't --

question: What do you mean?
answer: Don't be dim.

question: Elena, what are you're talking about?

question: Listen, Elena, if you're gonna pull that passive aggressive stuff on me again --
answer: Your unfaithfulness -- that's what I'm trying to talk about. Your unfaithfulness. Your betrayal. Your dalliance. And you won't do me the dignity of being up front about it.

question: Am I unfaithful? Is that what you're trying to say?
answer: It's a starting place.

question: Well, what kind of faithfulness are you after?
answer: If you're going to insult me --

question: What else could I be? What else could I be? We're not living in the real world here. It's the law of the land... the government, the world, those two guys on the Yankees... And I'm not having any fun at it, I can tell you that. I'm not...

You want to wear that, and you want me to shake hands with your friends and make conversation and dress up in an outfit that shows a lot of cleavage and you're not going to accord me the respect of talking honestly about this... You don't really know what this feels like.

question: Sure I do. Do I know what loneliness feels like? Sure I do. I know a lot about it, if that's what you mean.
answer: Benjamin. That's supposed to explain it? We're going to the Halford's. The number's on the calendar in the kitchen. We should be home around

answer: (eyes still glued to the

question: I suppose. Why?

question: What sort of problems are you planning exactly?
answer: Oh I thought I'd steal the station wagon, drive up to a commune. Or set the house on fire. You know.

question: Oh, damn. Uh, I've left the --
answer: You've...

question: In the car.
answer: Oh, yeah. Yeah, we'll be right back, Dot.

question: This just isn't the best moment for this.

question: Well?
answer: I think we're here and we don't have to stay -- we ought simply to put in an appearance and then we can head home.

question: Damn it, Ben --
answer: I'm not staying at this party so we can go home with someone else's wife. That's not why we're here, right? We're simply being neighbors here, and I think we should do just that --

question: You're not going to --
answer: I'm not.

question: You have some marker, that's what I think, if you want to know the truth. You have some marker and you're going to put it on the house keys so that Janey can find them and then when I get back to the house I'll find the two of you in there and Wendy'll be able to hear you and Paul will be back and he'll hear you and I'll catch you, that's what I think. She'll be swearing and banging against the wall and I'll catch --
answer: Elena. Elena, it's not what you think. It's not a big plot. Honestly. Honestly. I don't know if you want to go over this now, but it's just something that comes over me. I don't feel good about it. I know I've done what I didn't want to do. I don't know --

question: Well, I'm really pleased to hear a confession.
answer: Elena, you're just getting wound up to get wound up.

question: Benjie!
answer: Clair, George Clair! What the hell brings you to New Canaan?

question: Well, it's the funniest thing. I've been talking to some investors -- a little outside venture, you understand, between you and me -- about a scheme to manufacture a new Styrofoam packaging. Little peanut like pieces that can really keep an item free from trauma during shipping. Miraculous. Anyway, it turns out the genius behind the whole project is your neighbor, Jim Williams. How about that!
answer: Well, hey, isn't that a one-in-a million coincidence. A real dreamer, Jim Williams, eh?

question: Darned right. Look here, Benj, whaddya make of this sequel to The Godfather? You think it's gonna work?
answer: Don't see how. I think the public's had its fill of this gangster stuff. No, trust me -- disaster pics. And air hockey.

question: Yeah, good. Well, gonna make a break for the hors d'oeuvres guy.
answer: Yeah, see you bright and early Monday am. Say, where's the wife?

question: Oh jeez, Benjie. Well, here you are.
answer: Damn right, but where the hell were you?

question: What are you talking about?
answer: Don't bullshit me around, Janey. Jesus Christ, I waited around for more than half an hour, in nothing but my boxer shorts, and -- and what's all that about? What the hell happened?

question: A prior engagement overcame me.
answer: What?

question: Listen, Benjamin Hood. I have obligations that precede your... from before you showed up. One or two, you know, good-natured encounters, that doesn't mean I'm... I'm not just some toy for you. When I remembered some chores I wanted to get done before the party, I just did them, that's all, because I wanted to do them before I saw Jimmy.
answer: Jimmy? Jimmy? I don't know how to take this. And what do you mean, Jimmy? I thought you said you and your husband --

question: How you take it isn't all that interesting to me, Benjamin. I'm sorry --
answer: I just can't believe you could be so -- Thanks for the advice Dave. Uh, well, what the hey... Good shit. It's what? Darn it, Dave.

question: Ouch! Stupid. Hood residence.
answer: You're parents at that party?

question: Yeah. Yours?
answer: You get in trouble?

question: Maybe. Can't really tell yet.
answer: I'm sorry if I got you into trouble. Maybe we don't have to, you know... unless you really want to.

question: Reverend Edwards.
answer: Perhaps you might find it in your heart to call me Philip?

question: You're here... I'm a bit surprised.
answer: Sometimes the shepherd needs the company of the sheep.

question: I'm going to try hard not to understand the implications of that simile.
answer: Forgive me.

question: Eureka. Valium. Seconal. Uh, Par-er-goric? Francis Chamberlain Davenport the Fourth -- tonight you sleep the sleep of the just. And whence has yon virginal maiden absconded?
answer: Like into one of the other 20 or so bathrooms they've got in this place.

question: Check it out. Not for the faint of heart.
answer: Pharmaceutical! You are a god.

question: Let's see!
answer: Libbets, you really shouldn't mix and match, you know with the beer. I'll put 'em back.

question: Oh far out, Paulie. Hey look, these expired like five months ago. You think they're better aged?
answer: Maybe you should have just a half.

question: I guess he's just real exhausted from, you know, tests and stuff.
answer: Yeah.

question: You know Libbets, I really feel, you know, like a real connection to you --
answer: Yeah but you don't even know me really.

question: Sure I do, you know, like your aura. That you give off.
answer: My what?

question: It's like very positive, and I feel a real special feeling, because you really --
answer: And I have a special feeling too, because I do. It's special.

question: You do? I'm glad. Because I feel for you --
answer: And I have a feeling for you too, because you're just like -- I feel for you like you're -- you're just like --

question: Yeah, you're not alone with that line.
answer: I do.

question: Right. Cool. So, how about we take a bath together?
answer: Hah hah you're funny. A bath. Like a brother and sister. Oh man, I'm so wasted.

question: Hood residence.
answer: Charles, what time is it?

question: Is this Charles?
answer: What time is it?

question: Um, ten-o-five. Why? Where are you?
answer: I'm, uh, in the midst of a moral dilemma. And I was wondering, because I know you're a very moral person, and --

question: And?
answer: Shit. I can't really talk about it. I guess I better get to the train.

question: Right.
answer: What are you doing at home on a Friday night?

question: Rob, we'll fix it for ourselves. You two go and get acquainted. We'll let ourselves out the front door.
answer: Well, I have to say I don't have much faith that my car keys are still in that bowl. Doesn't seem entirely safe, leaving your car keys around?

question: Let me.
answer: Thanks, but -- oh, I don't think so. It's been kind of a discouraging evening.

question: You couldn't have hoped for much better when you came up the walk.
answer: Somehow it was different in my imagination when I thought about it. Actually, I didn't think about it at all, really. You want coffee or something?

question: Well, maybe they have one of those filter jobs in the kitchen --
answer: Look, Elena, the fact that we're neighbors... you know, close friends, well it sort of makes this a little strange, don't you think?

question: My husband is probably passed out in the bathroom, or at least he wishes he were. I've been married to him for 17 years and I don't have any intention of going in there to get him... so what I'm proposing is that since your wife has gone off with a boy, and since you are standing here alone, I'm proposing that you and I do what makes sense. Stay warm. Pass some time. That's all. Now don't make me feel as if I'm being too forward, OK? If you don't
answer: What the hey. Let's go for a drive.

question: Okay. Shall we clean up around here first? Do you think it's all right--
answer: Nah, that wasn't in the contract. We're going to have to defrost this thing for a while.

question: Do these seats go back?
answer: That was awful, really awful. I'm so sorry, Elena. Things are really rotten at home. You wouldn't believe how rotten. Janey's sick. She's unstable, I guess... it's not the right time to tell you... but that's it -- it's like I can't make her happy, the boys can't make her happy, she just doesn't --

question: Jim, maybe we should just go. I've got to look in on the kids. Paul is supposed to be coming back in from the city.
answer: Jesus, let me make it up to you -- I can do better than that, honestly

question: Well, we can talk about it.
answer: That's fine. I wouldn't expect you to see it any other way.

question: Maybe you just need -- look, can you wait here a sec, I need to tidy up -- just a minute, I'll be right back. You'll wait?
answer: Of course.

question: Elena.
answer: Ben, I've got a ride home. Maybe you should sleep this one off on the couch here?

question: I'll drive you --
answer: Ben. You're in no condition to drive. We'll talk in the morning, OK? You'll get some sleep on the couch out there?

question: Sure. I'll try. And we'll talk in the morning?
answer: We'll talk in the morning.

question: Anyone home? Hello.
answer: Wendy.

question: Sandy, you scared the shit out of me.
answer: What are you doing?

question: Just thought I'd stop by.
answer: Mike's out -- I think he went to Silver Meadow to see if you were hanging around there.

question: Yeah.
answer: Are you his girlfriend?

question: Check this out. He's supposed to talk all kinds of stuff, but he's like malfunctioned. Same thing. Again and again. It's gonna get a lot colder tonight, I predict. Probably a blackout. Do you have candles in your house? I know where the candles are, and I have my own flashlight. Over there. Also, I know where every emergency exit is on this floor. This knot's called a bowline. Let's hang him.
answer: He's dead.

question: If it wasn't raining we could take him outside and blow him up.
answer: He wouldn't blow up. He'd just get all mangled or twisted. Well. It looks like someone got to his private parts before us.

question: Communist Viet Cong.
answer: They left it in the jungle. Can I get into your bed? With you?

question: We -- we have to go to the guest room. We can't stay in here. What if Mikey? My parents?
answer: Don't worry about them. They're at that party, getting drunk and falling all over each other and making jokes about McGovern and stuff.

question: It's just -- it's just --
answer: Want a drink?

question: Vodka?
answer: You never tasted the stuff? Try again.

question: It feels warm.
answer: One more shot?

question: Okay.
answer: Under the covers. Get 'em off. Have you ever had a nocturnal emission?

question: Huh?
answer: That's the name for when you wake up and find this little pool of sticky stuff, like after a sexy dream. They didn't tell you this stuff yet? What planet do you live on?

question: I love you.
answer: That's nice. Are you drunk?

question: I don't know. How do I know?
answer: I don't know either. You spin around, when you lie down.

question: Ben?
answer: Jim -- he was just up -- in Silver Lane -- I think maybe -- a power line -- Do you think? Maybe we should call someone --

question: The phone's out.
answer: Yeah. Well, we can just --
